commit_message:
Add gate hook scripts for functional tests

Add gate hook to contrib/ci dir to be able to configure functional tests job.

pre_test_hook just imports devstack extension for manila project to the
devstack project.
post_test_hook configures config file for manilaclient based on devstack
installation and runs related tox job.

Also fix default config file path within config module.

Partially implements bp functional-tests

Change-Id: Ibf90af083b9a8e0ec646e1bff676893528ff1914
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient refs/changes/32/134132/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xe # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # This script is executed inside post_test_hook function in devstack gate. # Go to the manilaclient dir cd $BASE/new/python-manilaclient # Create manilaclient config file export MANILACLIENT_CONF="etc/manilaclient/manilaclient.conf" # Import 'iniset' func from devstack functions source $BASE/new/devstack/functions # Set options to config client. source $BASE/new/devstack/accrc/demo/demo iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT username $OS_USERNAME iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT tenant_name $OS_TENANT_NAME iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT password $OS_PASSWORD iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT auth_url $OS_AUTH_URL source $BASE/new/devstack/accrc/demo/admin iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT admin_username $OS_USERNAME iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT admin_tenant_name $OS_TENANT_NAME iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT admin_password $OS_PASSWORD iniset $MANILACLIENT_CONF DEFAULT admin_auth_url $OS_AUTH_URL # Run functional tests sudo -H -u jenkins tox -e functional

commit_message:
Adds host power actions support for Hyper-V

This patch introduces host power off and host reboot
support for the Nova Hyper-V driver.

Startup cannot be supported as the driver runs on the
host itself.

Implements: blueprint hyper-v-host-power-actions

Change-Id: I86ca35ff2527f643d72fb949870da69ce63277ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/79/127279/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.i18n import _ def host_power_action(self, action): if action in ["shutdown", "reboot"]: self._hostutils.host_power_action(action) else: if action == "startup": msg = _("Host PowerOn is not supported by the Hyper-V driver") raise NotImplementedError(msg)

commit_message:
Add requirement for APIImpact flag

Adds a requirement for an APIImpact flag in
the commit message for a proposed spec if it proposes
changes to the Trove REST API. This will make it
much easier for people such as the API WG who want to
review API changes across OpenStack to find and
review proposed API changes.

Change-Id: Ic3a6c3ef65fc0ccbdffe24903faf7c7a99d49d88
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/46/132346/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If your specification proposes any changes to the Trove REST API such as changing parameters which can be returned or accepted, or even the semantics of what happens when a client calls into the API, then you should add the APIImpact flag to the commit message. Specifications with the APIImpact flag can be found with the following query: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/trove-specs+message:apiimpact,n,z

added_lines: environments = self.parser.listing(self.murano('environment-list')) packages = self.parser.listing(self.murano('package-list'))
deleted_lines: import time import uuid environments = self.listing('environment-list') packages = self.listing('package-list') def test_table_struct_of_environment_create(self): env_name = "gg" + uuid.uuid4().hex environment = self.listing('environment-create', params=env_name) self.assertTableStruct(environment, ['ID', 'Name', 'Created', 'Updated']) def test_table_struct_of_environment_delete(self): env_name = "gg" + uuid.uuid4().hex environment = self.listing('environment-create', params=env_name) ID = self.get_value('ID', 'Name', env_name, environment) delete_env = self.listing('environment-delete', params=ID) self.assertTableStruct(delete_env, ['ID', 'Name', 'Created', 'Updated']) class EnvironmentMuranoClientTest(muranoclient.ClientTestBase): @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(EnvironmentMuranoClientTest, cls).setUpClass() def test_environment_create(self): env_name = "gg" + uuid.uuid4().hex environment = self.listing('environment-create', params=env_name) environment_list = self.listing('environment-list') self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment]) self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment_list]) def test_environment_delete(self): env_name = "gg" + uuid.uuid4().hex environments = self.listing('environment-create', params=env_name) ID = self.get_value('ID', 'Name', env_name, environments) self.listing('environment-delete', params=ID) start_time = time.time() while env_name in [env['Name'] for env in self.listing('environment-list')]: if start_time - time.time() > 60: self.fail("Environment is not deleted in 60 seconds") def test_environment_show(self): env_name = "gg" + uuid.uuid4().hex environment = self.listing('environment-create', params=env_name) ID = self.get_value('ID', 'Name', env_name, environment) created = self.get_value('Created', 'Name', env_name, environment) updated = self.get_value('Updated', 'Name', env_name, environment) show_env = self.listing('environment-show', params=ID) self.assertEqual(env_name, self.get_value('Value', 'Property', 'name', show_env)) self.assertEqual(created, self.get_value('Value', 'Property', 'created', show_env)) self.assertEqual(updated, self.get_value('Value', 'Property', 'updated', show_env)) def test_environment_rename(self): env_name = "gg" + uuid.uuid4().hex environment = self.listing('environment-create', params=env_name) ID = self.get_value('ID', 'Name', env_name, environment) new_name = uuid.uuid4().hex rename_env = self.listing('environment-rename', params='{id} {name}'.format(id=ID, name=new_name)) show_env = self.listing('environment-show', params=ID) self.assertEqual(new_name, self.get_value('Name', 'ID', ID, rename_env)) self.assertEqual(new_name, self.get_value('Value', 'Property', 'name', show_env))

Use canonical name for coverage job

Use "cover" for the coverage tox environment.  Also removed the unused
tox environment previously using "cover" as the name.

commit_message:
Custom variables

On creating a solum app, user can upload custom
variables via --param-file option.

Change-Id: I653aec30881759f9a7fbe20b54abd39e343a61b5

added_lines: from solumclient.common import yamlutils self.parser.add_argument('--param-file', dest='param_file', help="Parameter file") plan_definition = definition_file.read() definition = yamlutils.load(plan_definition) if args.param_file: with open(args.param_file) as param_f: param_definition = param_f.read() definition['parameters'] = yamlutils.load(param_definition) plan = self.client.plans.create(yamlutils.dump(definition))

commit_message:
Return the correct RRSet object in Central.create_recordset

Previously, we returned the input RecordSet, rather than the newly
created RecordSet object. This likely hasn't caused any harm, but
was inconsistent with all the other create_ methods.

Change-Id: I75342cda4e1d7a46a28d471261d51c954c333f2b

commit_message:
Bug in CLI when pointing to Solum API directly

The Solum_url property is being deleted and used later.
This is a bug and won't allow the CLI to talk to the
Solum API directly. There is no need to delete it.

Change-Id: I58a898833909d652e667818101672482f49a7114

commit_message:
Add some helpful SQL indices

Adds a few SQL indices that improve performance significantly as
the Designate database grows in size.

Change-Id: If68b3f7883487e5379e7ab45f51a27ef7ecb2f58
Blueprint: add-indices

commit_message:
Add keystone session support to client

To support keystone v3 requires support of keystone sessions,
which handle authenticating and creating http requests. In itself
this patch doesn't make anything new happen and should be followed
by another that tells the CLI to use SessionClient, but it adds
the support to do so.

Change-Id: I77093fbe6db968cfa6fa4ef71caa800573f7736e
Partially-implements: blueprint support-keystone-v3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/09/131309/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class SessionClient(HTTPClient): """Keystone-session-based client""" def __init__(self, session, auth, endpoint, **kwargs): self.session = session self.auth = auth self.endpoint = endpoint self.region_name = kwargs.get('region_name') self.interface = kwargs.get('interface', kwargs.get('endpoint_type', 'public')) self.service_type = kwargs.get('service_type') def _http_request(self, url, method, **kwargs): kwargs.setdefault('user-agent', USER_AGENT) kwargs.setdefault('auth', self.auth) endpoint_filter = kwargs.setdefault('endpoint_filter', {}) endpoint_filter.setdefault('interface', self.interface) endpoint_filter.setdefault('service_type', self.service_type) endpoint_filter.setdefault('region_name', self.region_name) # Allow overriding of redirect following, in cases # where code wants to intentionally handle it follow_redirects = kwargs.pop('follow_redirects', True) if self.endpoint: kwargs['endpoint_override'] = self.endpoint resp = self.session.request(url, method, redirect=follow_redirects, raise_ex=False, **kwargs) if 400 <= resp.status_code < 600: raise exc.from_response(resp) elif resp.status_code in (300, 302, 305): if follow_redirects: location = resp.headers.get('location') path = self.strip_endpoint(location) resp = self._http_request(path, method, **kwargs) elif resp.status_code == 300: raise exc.from_response(resp) return resp def _construct_http_client(*args, **kwargs): session = kwargs.pop('session', None) auth = kwargs.pop('auth', None) if session: return SessionClient(session, auth, *args, **kwargs) else: return HTTPClient(*args, **kwargs)

commit_message:
add list_opts to all modules with configuration options

this allows these modules to be exposed as entry points, and consumed by
oslo-config-generator.

Co-Authored-By: Dolph Mathews <dolph.mathews@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ben Nemec <bnemec@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I7f0ed83cc87a9647c341641134cefbb966d23bee
Closes-Bug: 1356438

commit_message:
Change DHCP network schedule interface to accept id

Currently passing whole network dict to schedule() method is
redundant. Scheduler can query network directly if it needs it.
Fix UT accordingly

Change-Id: Ifb340afc8bd58c33df1505ad0ca2ba160f05d72c

commit_message:

according pytest best practices.

commit_message:
Add default file I/O implementation for volume migration

This patch adds a default implementation for the volume open and close
methods.  These methods assume volumes are attachable and serve as an
initial working implementation to next add specific support for
non-attachable volumes.

Related-Blueprint: generic-volume-migration
Change-Id: Ie8ae18c33d0f9750ac1ba8404167f1a1176039f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/87/116787/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import eventletfrom cinder.openstack.common import units def open_volume(self, context, volume, remote, attachable, mode='rb'): The mode can be 'rb' or 'wb' for reading (default) or writing. This # For a local volume, the specific driver is expected to override this # method if the default implementation is not suitable. Remote volumes # that support attachment can be accessed in the usual way as well # through _attach_volume(). However, non-attachable remote volumes # need special treatment. if remote and not attachable: raise NotImplementedError() properties = utils.brick_get_connector_properties() saved_status = volume['status'] try: attach_info = self._attach_volume(context, volume, properties, remote=remote) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): msg = _("Failed to attach volume %(vol)s") LOG.error(msg % {'vol': volume['id']}) self.db.volume_update(context, volume['id'], {'status': saved_status}) volume_path = attach_info['device']['path'] try: with utils.temporary_chown(volume_path): handle = open(volume_path, mode) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): msg = _("Failed to open volume %(vol)s") LOG.error(msg % {'vol': volume['id']}) self.db.volume_update(context, volume['id'], {'status': saved_status}) return {'handle': handle, 'private': attach_info} volume_file['handle'].close() attach_info = volume_file['private'] properties = utils.brick_get_connector_properties() self._detach_volume(context, attach_info, volume, properties, force=True, remote=remote) def _transfer_data(self, src, dest, length, chunksize): """Transfer data between files (Python IO objects).""" # TODO(jbernard): This function is duplicated in the backup driver. chunks = int(length / chunksize) src.seek(0) dest.seek(0) for chunk in xrange(0, chunks): data = src.read(chunksize) if data == '': return dest.write(data) dest.flush() # yield to any other pending backups eventlet.sleep(0) rem = int(length % chunksize) if rem: data = src.read(rem) if data != '': dest.write(data) dest.flush() def _copy_data_using_files(self, context, src_vol, dest_vol, remote, attachable): src_remote = True if remote in ['src', 'both'] else False dest_remote = True if remote in ['dest', 'both'] else False src_attachable = True if attachable in ['src', 'both'] else False dest_attachable = True if attachable in ['dest', 'both'] else False # Open the destination volume for writing try: dest_file = self.open_volume(context, dest_vol, dest_remote, dest_attachable, 'wb') except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): msg = _("Failed to open destination volume %(vol)s") LOG.error(msg % {'vol': dest_vol['id']}) # Open the source volume for reading try: src_file = self.open_volume(context, src_vol, src_remote, src_attachable) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): msg = _("Failed to open source volume %(vol)s") LOG.error(msg % {'vol': src_vol['id']}) self.close_volume(context, dest_vol, dest_file, dest_remote) self._transfer_data(src_file['handle'], dest_file['handle'], int(src_vol['size']) * units.Gi, units.Mi * 4) self.close_volume(context, dest_vol, dest_file, dest_remote) self.close_volume(context, src_vol, src_file, src_remote) src_is_attachable = self.is_attachable() dest_is_attachable = rpcapi.is_attachable(context, dest_vol['host']) if src_is_attachable and dest_is_attachable: attachable = [] if src_is_attachable: attachable.update('src') if dest_is_attachable: attachable.update('dest') self._copy_data_using_files(context, src_vol, dest_vol, remote, attachable)

This return NotImplementedError() return NotImplementedError() def _copy_data_using_files(self, context, src_vol, dest_vol, remote): msg = _("migration using file I/O is not yet supported") raise exception.VolumeMigrationFailed(reason=msg) src_is_attachable = self.is_attachable() dst_is_attachable = rpcapi.is_attachable(context, dest_vol['host']) if src_is_attachable and dst_is_attachable: self._copy_data_using_files(context, src_vol, dest_vol, remote)

commit_message:
Add volume migration support for source RBD volumes

This patch implements the volume open and close routines allowing volume
migration when the source volume is of type RBD to succeed.  RBD
destination volumes are still to come.

Related-Blueprint: generic-volume-migration
Change-Id: Iffadb089f6c610f7c89dae718ffd28287e6f035a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/31/117031/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Opens an rbd volume.""" # For volume migration, this function is called from the source volume # context for both the source and destination volumes. Since the # source volume is local, connecting to the rbd image is simple. If # the volume is remote, it may not even be and RBD volume and must be # handled by the base class. if remote: return super(RBDDriver, self).open_volume(context, volume, remote, attachable, mode) with RBDVolumeProxy(self, volume['name'], self.configuration.rbd_pool) as rbd_image: rbd_meta = RBDImageMetadata(rbd_image, self.configuration.rbd_pool, self.configuration.rbd_user, self.configuration.rbd_ceph_conf) handle = RBDImageIOWrapper(rbd_meta) return {'handle': handle, 'private': rbd} """Closes an rbd volume.""" volume_file['private'].close()
deleted_lines: raise Exception(_("Volume open operation is not yet supported")) raise Exception(_("Volume close operation is not yet supported"))

subject: Introduce changes necessary for generic volume migration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-11 17:58:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/588a838a1117e3379fce254308a0b5f03c30a32c', 'message': "Introduce changes necessary for generic volume migration

This patch contains the core driver changes needed to make generic
volume migration possible.  By itself, no changes to the existing logic
for volume migration are introduced.  The intent is to keep the original
behaviour intact while allowing certain drivers that cannot attach
volumes locally to still participate in volume migration.

To allow this functionality, an 'is_attachable' function is added to the
volume driver definition.  This property indicates whether the volume
can be attached locally to the host and expose a path to the resulting
block device.  A driver author can override this and return False if
a driver cannot attach its volumes in a way that exposes a block device
path.  Doing so will cause the volume copy routine (copy_volume_data) to
use file I/O instead of calling out to `dd`.  The driver author is
expected to provide an implementation of open_volume() that returns
a file object capable of proxying I/O requests to the underlying storage
backend.

An RPC call for 'is_attachable' is added to allow querying of remote
volume capabilities.

The default volume open and close routines are currently unimplemented
and are the next step in this series.  The open routine will return
a file handle defined by the path to the block device.  This will allow
drivers like RBD which do not support attachment to migrate to and from
drivers which do support attachment, such as LVM.

Related-Blueprint: generic-volume-migration
Change-Id: I96bb677fb89f7e1721572bca9ed48995df33bcd0

commit_message:
Introduce changes necessary for generic volume migration

This patch contains the core driver changes needed to make generic
volume migration possible.  By itself, no changes to the existing logic
for volume migration are introduced.  The intent is to keep the original
behaviour intact while allowing certain drivers that cannot attach
volumes locally to still participate in volume migration.

To allow this functionality, an 'is_attachable' function is added to the
volume driver definition.  This property indicates whether the volume
can be attached locally to the host and expose a path to the resulting
block device.  A driver author can override this and return False if
a driver cannot attach its volumes in a way that exposes a block device
path.  Doing so will cause the volume copy routine (copy_volume_data) to
use file I/O instead of calling out to `dd`.  The driver author is
expected to provide an implementation of open_volume() that returns
a file object capable of proxying I/O requests to the underlying storage
backend.

An RPC call for 'is_attachable' is added to allow querying of remote
volume capabilities.

The default volume open and close routines are currently unimplemented
and are the next step in this series.  The open routine will return
a file handle defined by the path to the block device.  This will allow
drivers like RBD which do not support attachment to migrate to and from
drivers which do support attachment, such as LVM.

Related-Blueprint: generic-volume-migration
Change-Id: I96bb677fb89f7e1721572bca9ed48995df33bcd0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/29/113329/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def fake_is_attachable(self, ctxt, host): return True def fake_copy_data_using_files(self, ctx, src, dst, remote): raise Exception('should not be called') self.stubs.Set(self.volume.driver, '_copy_data_using_files', fake_copy_data_using_files) self.stubs.Set(self.volume.driver, '_copy_data_using_paths', lambda x, y, z, remote='dest': True) self.stubs.Set(volume_rpcapi.VolumeAPI, 'is_attachable', fake_is_attachable)
deleted_lines: self.stubs.Set(self.volume.driver, 'copy_volume_data', lambda x, y, z, remote='dest': True)

commit_message:
Promote check-grenade-dsvm-neutron to voting job

After https://review.openstack.org/#/c/134484 is merged we should make
neutron grenade job voting in order to avoid breakage of this job in the
future.

Change-Id: I1b3d2d30479f1a51d534a48d815b84ce1ed5f317

commit_message:
Test nodepool provided addresses in aiopcpu setup

Existing change determines node IPs by interrogating the `ip` command on
each host. Nodepool provides info about the public IP of each host to
the test nodes. Just use the nodepool provided IPs.

Change-Id: Iaad8b25fa8606fa77daa2f6096c8b1a6a5d146ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/97/131297/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local primary_node=`cat /etc/nodepool/primary_node` PRIMARY_NODE=`cat /etc/nodepool/primary_node` SUB_NODES=`cat /etc/nodepool/sub_nodes`
deleted_lines: local primary_node=`get_default_host_ip $FIXED_RANGE $FLOATING_RANGE` PRIMARY_NODE=`get_default_host_ip $FIXED_RANGE $FLOATING_RANGE` SUB_NODES=$(for NODE in $(cat /etc/nodepool/sub_nodes); do remote_command $NODE "source $WORKSPACE/test_env.sh; source $WORKSPACE/devstack-gate/functions.sh; get_default_host_ip $FIXED_RANGE $FLOATING_RANGE" done)

commit_message:
Add volume_api_version for dashboard configurations

For Horizon localsetting, it can configure to use which version of cinder api.
Now the cookbook is switching to adopt cinder v2 api, we need to have horizon
cookbook support cinder v2 as well.

Change-Id: I2ab95c9f55cadd37d26c1d0af0dbd64cd8fc8e2c

commit_message:
Several fixes for Cinder/Neutron plugins spec

* fixed typo
* `fuel_version` is a list, not a string
* add `title` field

Change-Id: I71b853948f600cfb1ce350107c251032ecdc67b6

added_lines: Puppet::Type.newtype(:cinder_config) do ensurable newparam(:name, :namevar => true) do desc 'Section/setting name to manage from /etc/cinder/cinder.conf' newvalues(/\S+\/\S+/) end newproperty(:value) do desc 'The value of the setting to be defined.' munge do |value| value = value.to_s.strip value.capitalize! if value =~ /^(true|false)$/i value end def is_to_s( currentvalue ) if resource.secret? return '[old secret redacted]' else return currentvalue end end def should_to_s( newvalue ) if resource.secret? return '[new secret redacted]' else return newvalue end end end newparam(:secret, :boolean => true) do desc 'Whether to hide the value from Puppet logs. Defaults to `false`.' newvalues(:true, :false) defaultto false end end

subject: add a Rakefile to structure test runs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-17 10:58:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-integration-test/commit/6ec28fc1c7384efe041db8d9fc1d6e4cd9d9ed4f', 'message': "add a Rakefile to structure test runs

Having a Rakefile will allow us to change the actual test commands on
our side rather than relying on changes to the openstack-infra
repository. This should make it a lot faster to change things, but also
easier to test since the jenkins jobs are actually run in this
repository, not the openstack-infra one.

This commit defines the jobs we previously had defined in Jenkins and
uses 'high-level' naming consistently (i.e. lint, style vs. foodcritic,
rubocop).

There is also a :clean task to help with deleting the files generated by
the other jobs.

Also changed foodcritic to run on the source cookbook rather than the
one installed by berks, see
e.g. https://github.com/berkshelf/berkshelf/issues/931#issuecomment-29668369

commit_message:
add a Rakefile to structure test runs

Having a Rakefile will allow us to change the actual test commands on
our side rather than relying on changes to the openstack-infra
repository. This should make it a lot faster to change things, but also
easier to test since the jenkins jobs are actually run in this
repository, not the openstack-infra one.

This commit defines the jobs we previously had defined in Jenkins and
uses 'high-level' naming consistently (i.e. lint, style vs. foodcritic,
rubocop).

There is also a :clean task to help with deleting the files generated by
the other jobs.

Also changed foodcritic to run on the source cookbook rather than the
one installed by berks, see
e.g. https://github.com/berkshelf/berkshelf/issues/931#issuecomment-29668369

Change-Id: Id085444027efd90049508abe6a309fed7dfffee8

commit_message:
Make utils.universalUnmount work with all components

There was a common pattern to universally unmount any React component.
Now it doesn't work with component which render to null, so I created
this workaround and a bug in React's Github:

https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/2545

Closes-Bug: #1393367

Change-Id: Id7f7b8f4daa7f4d8272a1fe8362cbad31f680a12
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/51/134951/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add uuid hex check before updating the quotas

In current nova api, there is no constraints for quota updates with provided
tenant_id or user_id arguments. User can use tenant_name or user_name for update
and get operation success but actually these quotas does not take effect for
deployments. Only quota updates with ids could work. This fix will validate
uuid format before quota updates.

For tenant_id or user_id validation by keystone, it's covered in blueprint
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/validate-tenant-user-with-keystone
which is pendding approval.

Change-Id: Ie84f4b93893a76f041be754e25e9c17b37e854aa
Closes-Bug: #1333571
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/102147/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid def _is_uuid_hex(self, hex_val): try: uuid_val = uuid.UUID(hex_val) except (TypeError, ValueError, AttributeError): return False return uuid_val.hex == hex_val if project_id is not None and not self._is_uuid_hex(project_id): msg = _("Please use tenant_id to update the quota.") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) if user_id is not None and not self._is_uuid_hex(user_id): msg = _("Please use user_id to update the quota.") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-12 11:38:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient/commit/abdb7528288aa7f247a6d1018e66cc7a2f4bad8f', 'message': "Mask token in debug output

Replaying the token in debug output is both completely burdensome to
read (given it's unbounded size), but it's also potentially a security
issue given that it could be used in replay attacks.

Instead, filter the headers to sha1 sensitive things, with X-Auth-Token
being the only one listed so far. The sha1 will at least give us the
understanding of tokens being the same or different (and an administrator
could use that to figure out if they were valid later).

debug logs, because they were not helping with readability.

logging path using the logging fixture. It's pretty basic, but does
verify that requests are logged at debug, that the SHA1 format works,
and that headers which are not listed get shown straight through.

DocImpact because this changes the curl dumped strings which people
may have been using. They can still do that as long as they generate
their own keystone token.

commit_message:
Mask token in debug output

Replaying the token in debug output is both completely burdensome to
read (given it's unbounded size), but it's also potentially a security
issue given that it could be used in replay attacks.

Instead, filter the headers to sha1 sensitive things, with X-Auth-Token
being the only one listed so far. The sha1 will at least give us the
understanding of tokens being the same or different (and an administrator
could use that to figure out if they were valid later).

This also removes some extra '\n' that were being injected into the
debug logs, because they were not helping with readability.

Lastly, actually test logging. This introduces the first tests of the
logging path using the logging fixture. It's pretty basic, but does
verify that requests are logged at debug, that the SHA1 format works,
and that headers which are not listed get shown straight through.

DocImpact because this changes the curl dumped strings which people
may have been using. They can still do that as long as they generate
their own keystone token.

(Patch and commit message inspired from Sean Dague's novaclient
implementation)

Change-Id: I728fc2db0590d5893d571ffcbf10b9b20821d147

deleted_lines: from swiftclient.utils import LengthWrapper for element in kwargs['headers']: header = ' -H "%s: %s"' % (element, kwargs['headers'][element])

added_lines: from eventlet import wsgi, listen, spawn, connect, sleep, greenio def test_auth_scheme_using_real_socket(self): # FormPost rejects key = 'abc' sig, env, body = self._make_sig_env_body( '/v1/AUTH_test/container', '', 1024, 10, int(time() - 10), key) full_body = '\r\n'.join(body) # Server serv_sock = listen(('localhost', 0)) ag = spawn(serv_sock.accept) sleep() clnt_sock = connect(serv_sock.getsockname()[:2]) cg = spawn(clnt_sock.sendall(full_body)) work_sock = ag.wait() env['wsgi.input'] = wsgi.Input(greenio.socket._fileobject(work_sock[0]), len(full_body)) env['swift.account/AUTH_test'] = self._fake_cache_env( 'AUTH_test', [key]) self.app = FakeApp(iter([('201 Created', {}, ''), ('201 Created', {}, '')])) self.auth = tempauth.filter_factory({})(self.app) self.formpost = formpost.filter_factory({})(self.auth) status = [None] headers = [None] exc_info = [None] def start_response(s, h, e=None): status[0] = s headers[0] = h exc_info[0] = e body = ''.join(self.formpost(env, start_response)) status = status[0] headers = headers[0] exc_info = exc_info[0] self.assertEquals(status, '401 Unauthorized') authenticate_v = None for h, v in headers: if h.lower() == 'www-authenticate': authenticate_v = v self.assertTrue('FormPost: Form Expired' in body) self.assertEquals('Swift realm="unknown"', authenticate_v)

commit_message:
Use identity_uri instead of auth fragments

The auth_host, auth_port, auth_protocol and auth_admin_prefix have been
combined into the identity_uri parameter in auth_token middleware. Swift
sample config files should reflect this.

Change-Id: Ia7060938db5c6db39bc43cab8d6950bdeabffe32
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/00/119300/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add --dry-run option to swift-ring-builder rebalance

The rebalanced ring is not written when used with option --dry-run.
This can be used to modify device weight and check for changes before
writing the modified ring, without the need to restore from the latest
version in directory backups/.

Change-Id: I5e9c407c0bf9ea9a61ca778a865878b57e9ebae2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/09/123009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: swift-ring-builder <builder_file> rebalance <seed> --dry-run The rebalanced ring is not written when used with option --dry-run. This can be used to modify device weight and check for changes before writing the modified ring. """ if argv[-1] == "--dry-run": print 'NOTE: dry run; not saving rebalanced ring.' exit(status)

commit_message:
Switch off Nova V2 XML Support

Tempest has a switch to disable tests that exercise the
Nova V2 XML API support. We need a way to enable/disable
this flag in devstack. Also we disable these tests by default.

Depends-On: Idd07587b0208f6ad4e34dc8fb112391c469c3ba2
Change-Id: I977fb6d72764d391b1c1b3b643968928792b34fd

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-06-16 09:12:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/88eea643e6c4509baa991c11537d4ae2c43fcdd5', 'message': 'Add distributed tracing capablities in logging.

Add trace capabilities in existing LogAdapter and minor fixes of object
and container server to propagate trace identification to form full
distributed trace stack.

Enable trace in configuration files of p/a/c/o servers:
    log_trace = true

To trace WSGI middleware, make sure of initializing self.logger by calling
get_logger() in utils.py. Then you can use the helper function to decorate
WSGI callable which requires environ and start_response arguments. e.g.
    @trace_wsgi()
    __call__(self, environ, start_response)

To trace deeper into the code, you can use three function of logger. But make
sure getting logger instance by calling get_logger() from utils.py before using
it.
    logger.start_trace(name, host, port, info)
    ...
    logger.trace_info(info)
    ...
    logger.stop_trace()

The trace info will be record into the logs by three trace calls and formatted
as:
    trace_tag: name host port time info (spn: span_id) \
    (psp: parent_id) (txn: trans_id)

Implements: blueprint tracing-tool
Change-Id: If25064e1d04380feb9609e106e627ece2262e16a

    logger.start_trace(name, host, port, info)
    ...
    logger.trace_info(info)
    ...
    logger.stop_trace(info)

The trace info will be recorded into the logs by three trace calls and
formatted as below:
    trace_tag: name host port time info (spn: span_id) (psp: parent_id) (txn: trans_id)

Implements: blueprint tracing-tool
Change-Id: If25064e1d04380feb9609e106e627ece2262e16a

commit_message:
Add distributed tracing capablities in logging.

Add trace capabilities in existing LogAdapter and minor fixes of object
and container server to propagate trace identification to form full
distributed trace stack.

Enable trace in configuration files of p/a/c/o servers:
    log_trace = true

To activate trace in WSGI middleware, make sure of initializing self.logger
by calling get_logger() in utils.py. Then you can use the helper function
to decorate WSGI callable which requires environ and start_response arguments.
e.g.
    @trace_wsgi
    __call__(self, environ, start_response)

To trace deeper into the code, you can use three new functions of logger as
below. But make sure getting logger instance by calling get_logger() from
utils.py before using it.
    logger.start_trace(name, host, port, info)
    ...
    logger.trace_info(info)
    ...
    logger.stop_trace(info)

The trace info will be recorded into the logs by three trace calls and
formatted as below:
    trace_tag: name host port time info (spn: span_id) (psp: parent_id) (txn: trans_id)

Implements: blueprint tracing-tool
Change-Id: If25064e1d04380feb9609e106e627ece2262e16a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/77/93677/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import json import math import string import sys import time import uuid from pymongo import MongoClient from urlparse import parse_qs class EVENT_TYPE: CLIENT_SEND = "cs" CLIENT_RECV = "cr" SERVER_SEND = "ss" SERVER_RECV = "sr" class ENDPOINT_TYPE: SERVER = 'server' MIDDLEWARE = 'middleware' class ANNOTATION_TYPE: TS = "timestamp" STRING = "string" INT = "integer" BYTES = "bytes" class ANNOTATION_KEY: REQUEST_PATH = 'request_path' RETURN_CODE = 'return_code' class TRACE_HEADERS: TraceId = "HTTP_X_TRACE_ID" SpanId = "HTTP_X_SPAN_ID" TransId = "HTTP_X_TRANS_ID" SampleRate = "HTTP_X_TRACE_SAMPLE_RATE" class Trace(object): def __init__(self, name, trace_id=None, span_id=None, parent_span_id=None, start_time=None, end_time=None, endpoint=None, annotations=[], sample_rate=1.0, tracer=None): self.name = name # If no trace_id and span_id are given we want to generate new # 64-bit integer ids. self.trace_id = trace_id or uuid.uuid4().hex self.span_id = span_id or uuid.uuid4().hex self.sample_rate = sample_rate # If no parent_span_id is given then we assume there is no parent span # and leave it as None. self.parent_span_id = parent_span_id self.start_time = start_time self.end_time = end_time # If no tracer are given we get the global tracer. self.tracer = tracer or _globalTracer # By default no endpoint will be associated with annotations recorded # to this trace. self.endpoint = endpoint self.annotations = annotations def set_start_time(self, t): self.start_time = t def set_end_time(self, t): self.end_time = t def get_span_time(self): return self.end_time - self.start_time def __eq__(self, other): return (self.trace_id, self.span_id, self.parent_span_id) ==\ (other.trace_id, other.span_id, other.parent_span_id) def __ne__(self, other): return not self == other def __repr__(self): return ( '{0.__class__.__name__}({0.name!r}, trace_id={0.trace_id!r}, ' 'span_id={0.span_id!r}, parent_span_id={0.parent_span_id!r})' ).format(self) def child(self, name): """ Create a new instance of this class derived from the current instance such that: (new.trace_id == current.trace_id and new.parent_span_id == current.span_id) The new L{Trace} instance will have a new unique span_id and if set the endpoint of the current L{Trace} object. @param name: C{str} name describing the new span represented by the new Trace object. @returns: L{Trace} """ trace = self.__class__(name, trace_id=self.trace_id, parent_span_id=self.span_id) trace.set_endpoint(self.endpoint) return trace def record(self, annotations): self.tracer.record([(self, annotations)]) def set_endpoint(self, endpoint): """ Set a default L{IEndpoint} provider for the current L{Trace}. All annotations recorded after this endpoint is set will use it, unless they provide their own endpoint. """ self.endpoint = endpoint class Endpoint(object): def __init__(self, name, ipv4, port, type): """ :param name: C{str} endpoint name. :param ipv4: C{str} ipv4 address. :param port: C{int} port number. :param type: C{str} endpoint type. """ self.name = name self.ipv4 = ipv4 self.port = port self.type = type def __eq__(self, other): if other is None: return False return (self.name, self.ipv4, self.port, self.type) ==\ (other.name, other.ipv4, other.port, other.type) def __ne__(self, other): return not self == other def __repr__(self): return ('{0.__class__.__name__}({0.name!r}, {0.ipv4!r}, {0.port!r}, ' '{0.type!r})').format(self) @classmethod def server(cls, name, ipv4, port): return cls(name, ipv4, port, ENDPOINT_TYPE.SERVER) @classmethod def middleware(cls, name, ipv4, port): return cls(name, ipv4, port, ENDPOINT_TYPE.MIDDLEWARE) class Annotation(object): def __init__(self, name, value, annotation_type, event_type=None, endpoint=None): """endpoint :param name: C{str} name of this annotation. :param value: A value of the appropriate type based on C{event_type}. :param event_type: C{str} the expected type of our C{value}. :param endpoint: An optional L{IEndpoint} provider to associate with this annotation or C{None} """ self.name = name self.value = value self.type = annotation_type self.event_type = event_type self.endpoint = endpoint def __eq__(self, other): return (self.name, self.value, self.type, self.event_type, self.endpoint) == (other.name, other.value, other.type, other.event_type, other.endpoint) def __ne__(self, other): return not self == other def __repr__(self): return ( '{0.__class__.__name__}({0.name!r}, {0.value!r}, ' '{0.type!r}, {0.event_type!r}, {0.endpoint})' ).format(self) @classmethod def timestamp(cls, name, timestamp=None, event_type=None): if timestamp is None: timestamp = math.trunc(time.time() * 1000 * 1000) return cls(name, timestamp, ANNOTATION_TYPE.TS, event_type) @classmethod def string(cls, name, value, event_type=None): return cls(name, value, ANNOTATION_TYPE.STRING, event_type=None) @classmethod def bytes(cls, name, value, event_type=None): return cls(name, value, ANNOTATION_TYPE.BYTES, event_type=None) @classmethod def request_path(cls, value): return cls(ANNOTATION_KEY.REQUEST_PATH, value, ANNOTATION_TYPE.STRING, EVENT_TYPE.SERVER_RECV) @classmethod def return_code(cls, value): return cls(ANNOTATION_KEY.RETURN_CODE, value, ANNOTATION_TYPE.STRING, EVENT_TYPE.SERVER_SEND) class Tracer(object): def __init__(self, destination=None): self.destination = destination def record(self, traces): pass class DebugTracer(Tracer): """ Send annotations immediately to a file-like destination in JSON format. All traces will be written immediately to the destination. :param destination: A file-like object to write JSON formatted traces to. """ def __init__(self, destination=None): self.destination = destination or sys.stdout def record(self, traces): #print json_formatter(traces, indent=2) self.destination.write(json_formatter(traces, indent=2)) self.destination.write('\n') self.destination.flush() class JsonFileTracer(Tracer): def __init__(self, destination=None): self.destination = destination def record(self, traces): with open(self.destination, 'a') as f: f.write(json_formatter(traces) + '\n') class SQLTracer(Tracer): def __init__(self, destination=None): self.destination = destination def record(self, traces): pass class MongoTracer(Tracer): def __init__(self, destination=None): self.destination = destination self.mclient = MongoClient(destination) self.db = self.mclient['xtrace'] self.collection = self.db['span'] def record(self, traces): traces_dict = traces_to_dict(traces) for trace in traces_dict: self.collection.save(trace) def get_trace_ids(self, skip=0, limit=20): cursor = self.collection.aggregate({'$group': {'_id': '$trace_id', 'count': {'$sum': 1}}}) return cursor['result'][skip: skip + limit] def get_trace(self, trace_id): cursor = self.collection.find({'trace_id': trace_id}) return [c for c in cursor] def get_span(self, span_id): cursor = self.collection.find({'_id': span_id}) return cursor[0] def format_oneline(self, span): rtime = span['start_time'] stime = span['end_time'] code = '' for ann in span['annotations']: if ann['key'] == ANNOTATION_KEY.RETURN_CODE: code = ann['value'] ts = 1000 * (float(stime) - float(rtime)) fmt_str = '%s, %s, %s, %s@%s:%s, %s, %s, %fms, %s~%s' line = fmt_str % (span['_id'][:4], span['parent'] if 'parent' in span.keys() else '-', span['trace_id'][:4], span['endpoint']['name'], span['endpoint']['ipv4'], span['endpoint']['port'], span['name'], code, ts, rtime, stime) return line def render_trace_in_text(self): try: cursor = self.collection.find({'parent': {'$exists': False}}) for parent in cursor: print '-' * 120 print '|%s' % self.format_oneline(parent) child_coll = self.collection.find({'parent': parent['_id']}) for child in child_coll: print '|..%s' % self.format_oneline(child) self.print_span(4, child['_id']) print '-' * 120 except Exception as ex: print ex def print_span(self, layer, pid): for child in self.collection.find({'parent': pid}): print '|%s%s' % ('.' * layer, self.format_oneline(child)) self.print_span(layer + 2, child['_id']) def render_trace_in_html(self, trace_id): content = """
${trace_tb}
Span Tree ${timeline}
""" try: trace_tb = [] spans = self.collection.find({'trace_id': trace_id, 'parent': {'$exists': False}}) max_ts = 0 #begin_time = float('inf') for s in spans: max_ts = max(max_ts, float(s['end_time']) - float(s['start_time'])) unit = max(1, int(max_ts * 1000 / 10 / 20)) label_ten_ms = int(max_ts * 1000 / 10 / unit) + 2 max_ts = label_ten_ms * unit * 10.0 / 1000 label_width = 1000.0 / label_ten_ms ruler = [] for i in range(label_ten_ms): ruler_div = "
%d
" %\ (label_width, i * 10 * unit) ruler.append(ruler_div) #render the ruler fof timing spans.rewind() c = spans.count() for s in spans: c = c - 1 begin_time = float(s['start_time']) ts = float(s['end_time']) - float(s['start_time']) width = 1000 * ts / max_ts left = 0 path, code = self.get_path_code(s['annotations']) trace_tr = "\ %s@%s:%s\
\ %10.3fms, %s %s, %s
%s" cs_html = self.render_span_in_html(s['_id'], 1, [c], begin_time, max_ts) trace_tb.append(trace_tr % (s['endpoint']['name'], s['endpoint']['ipv4'], s['endpoint']['port'], left, width, ts * 1000, s['name'], path, code, cs_html)) timeline = "
%s
" cdict = {'trace_tb': ''.join(trace_tb), 'timeline': timeline % ''.join(ruler)} return string.Template(content).substitute(cdict) except Exception as ex: print ex def render_span_in_html(self, pid, layer, pv, begin_time, max_ts): children_tr = [] spans = self.collection.find({'parent': pid}) c = spans.count() for child in spans: sv = pv + [c] c = c - 1 for i in range(len(sv) - layer): if sv[layer + i - 1] > 0: sv[layer + i - 1] = sv[layer + i - 1] - 1 ts = float(child['end_time']) - float(child['start_time']) width = 1000 * ts / max_ts left = int((float(child['start_time']) - begin_time) / max_ts * 1000) _, code = self.get_path_code(child['annotations']) span_tr = "%s%s@%s:%s\ \
%10.3fms, %s %s,\ %s
%s" prefix = '' for i in range(len(sv)): if sv[i] <= 0: prefix = prefix + ' ' * 3 else: if i == layer: prefix = prefix + '|--' else: prefix = prefix + '|  ' rc = self.render_span_in_html(child['_id'], layer + 1, sv, begin_time, max_ts) children_tr.append(span_tr % (prefix, child['endpoint']['name'], child['endpoint']['ipv4'], child['endpoint']['port'], left, width, 1000 * ts, child['name'], '', code, rc)) for i in range(len(sv) - layer): sv[-i - 1] = sv[-i - 1] + 1 sv.pop() return ''.join(children_tr) def get_path_code(self, annotations): path, code = None, None for ann in annotations: if ann['key'] == ANNOTATION_KEY.REQUEST_PATH: path = ann['value'] if ann['key'] == ANNOTATION_KEY.RETURN_CODE: code = ann['value'][:3] return path, code # the decoration function for WSGI callable which requires # environ and start_response arguments. # @trace_here() # __call__(self, environ, start_response) def trace_here(): def _outer(f): def _inner(*args, **kwargs): try: module_ns = args[0].__module__.split('.') name = ['.'.join(module_ns[-2:])] environ = args[1] start_response = args[2] trace_id = environ.get(TRACE_HEADERS.TraceId, None) # skip tracing if trace_id is not present. if trace_id is None: return f(*args, **kwargs) else: st = time.time() parent_id = environ.get(TRACE_HEADERS.SpanId, None) span_id = uuid.uuid4().hex environ[TRACE_HEADERS.TraceId] = trace_id environ[TRACE_HEADERS.SpanId] = span_id ann_list = [] # redefine new callable to record timing, # status code, headers etc. def trace_start_response(status, headers, exc_info=None): global _globalEndpoint try: path_info = environ.get('PATH_INFO', None) method = environ.get('REQUEST_METHOD', None) host_name = environ.get('SERVER_NAME', None) bind_port = environ.get('SERVER_PORT', None) ann_list.append(Annotation.request_path(path_info)) ann_list.append(Annotation.return_code(status)) et1 = time.time() trace = Trace(method, trace_id, span_id, parent_id, st, et1, 1.0) if 'server' in module_ns: endpoint = Endpoint.server(name[0], host_name, bind_port) elif 'middleware' in module_ns: endpoint = Endpoint.middleware(module_ns[-1], host_name, bind_port) else: endpoint = Endpoint(name[0], host_name, bind_port, args[0].__module__) trace.set_endpoint(endpoint) if _globalTracer: # calibrate the end time before recording et2 = time.time() trace.set_end_time(et2) _globalTracer.record([(trace, ann_list)]) except Exception as ex: start_response('400 Bad Request', [], ex) start_response(status, headers, exc_info) new_args = (args[0], environ, trace_start_response) return f(*new_args, **kwargs) except Exception as ex: return 'tracing error: %s' % ex return _inner return _outer def hex_str(n): return '%s' % (n,) def traces_to_dict(traces): dict_traces = [] for (trace, annotations) in traces: dict_trace = { 'trace_id': trace.trace_id, '_id': trace.span_id, 'name': trace.name, 'start_time': trace.start_time, 'end_time': trace.end_time, 'endpoint': {}, 'annotations': [] } if trace.parent_span_id: dict_trace['parent'] = trace.parent_span_id if trace.endpoint: dict_trace['endpoint'] = { 'name': trace.endpoint.name, 'ipv4': trace.endpoint.ipv4, 'port': trace.endpoint.port, 'type': trace.endpoint.type } for annotation in annotations: annotation_array = { 'key': annotation.name, 'value': annotation.value, 'type': annotation.type, 'event': annotation.event_type } dict_trace['annotations'].append(annotation_array) dict_traces.append(dict_trace) return dict_traces def json_formatter(traces, *json_args, **json_kwargs): return json.dumps(traces_to_dict(traces), *json_args, **json_kwargs) def _combine_body_qs(request): wsgi_input = request.environ['wsgi.input'] query_dict = request.params qs_in_body = wsgi_input.read() query_dict.update(parse_qs(qs_in_body, keep_blank_values=True, strict_parsing=False)) return query_dict _globalTracer = None _globalEndpoint = None if __name__ == '__main__': mt = MongoTracer() traces = [] endpoint = Endpoint('localhost', 8080, 'proxy-server', 'server') trace = Trace(name='POST', trace_id='trace_id', span_id='new_span_id', parent_span_id='parent_span_id', sample_rate=1.0, tracer=mt) annotation_aco = Annotation(name=ANNOTATION_KEY.REQUEST_PATH, value='req.path_info', annotation_type=ANNOTATION_TYPE.STRING, event_type=EVENT_TYPE.SERVER_RECV, endpoint=endpoint) traces.append((trace, [annotation_aco])) mt.record(traces)

subject: Include timestamp in diskfile create
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-27 21:52:37.000000000', 'files': ['swift/obj/server.py', 'swift/obj/mem_diskfile.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_diskfile.py', 'swift/obj/diskfile.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/17648d3ab5b552f8414b8304e51af1ad3b4b4598', 'message': "Include timestamp in diskfile create

In all known cases when creating a new DiskFileWriter with DiskFile.create the
final timestamp of the object to be created is known ahead of time, but not
exposed to the DiskFile implementation until the end of the write via metadata
in the call to put.

The timestamp of the newly created object is an important detail to the
default DiskFile implementation in it's handling of consistency and it's
on-disk layout; but the file system based implementation can avoid requring
this core piece of information until the very last call to the DiskFileWriter
because of the under-lying datastores support for atomic move.

For datastores which do not support atomic move (such as key value stores) it
can greatly simplify failure mode recovery if the final timestamp/version of
the object created is known before the very call to write.

With the introduction of the Timestamp class; there's a very small
simplification in the core implementation that falls out of not having to
reparse the string form of the timestamp provided in metadata to construct the
internalized timestamp used when creating the final on-disk name.

Because a new previously undescribed optional keyword is pushed into
DiskFile.create by swift.obj.server.ObjectController.PUT this change is
Backwards incompatible with existing implementations of DiskFile that did not
have the lucky foresight to accept **kwargs in their implementation of create
(e.g.  swift.obj.mem_diskfile.DiskFile.create).  When testing with the next
version of swift that includes this change diskfile maintainers who want to
continue to support the latest version will need to accept the new signature
for create but will not be required to adopt it and can maintain backwards
compatibility with older versions of swift simply by ignoring it and using the
timestamp provided in metadata as always.

Change-Id: I9d69ca26c3e590d174e3d936c2e4fd6e3acdbb74
"}]
commit_message:
Include timestamp in diskfile create

In all known cases when creating a new DiskFileWriter with DiskFile.create the
final timestamp of the object to be created is known ahead of time, but not
exposed to the DiskFile implementation until the end of the write via metadata
in the call to put.

The timestamp of the newly created object is an important detail to the
default DiskFile implementation in it's handling of consistency and it's
on-disk layout; but the file system based implementation can avoid requring
this core piece of information until the very last call to the DiskFileWriter
because of the under-lying datastores support for atomic move.

For datastores which do not support atomic move (such as key value stores) it
can greatly simplify failure mode recovery if the final timestamp/version of
the object created is known before the very call to write.

With the introduction of the Timestamp class; there's a very small
simplification in the core implementation that falls out of not having to
reparse the string form of the timestamp provided in metadata to construct the
internalized timestamp used when creating the final on-disk name.

Because a new previously undescribed optional keyword is pushed into
DiskFile.create by swift.obj.server.ObjectController.PUT this change is
Backwards incompatible with existing implementations of DiskFile that did not
have the lucky foresight to accept **kwargs in their implementation of create
(e.g.  swift.obj.mem_diskfile.DiskFile.create).  When testing with the next
version of swift that includes this change diskfile maintainers who want to
continue to support the latest version will need to accept the new signature
for create but will not be required to adopt it and can maintain backwards
compatibility with older versions of swift simply by ignoring it and using the
timestamp provided in metadata as always.

Change-Id: I9d69ca26c3e590d174e3d936c2e4fd6e3acdbb74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/59/117359/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def __init__(self, name, datadir, fd, tmppath, bytes_per_sync, threadpool): timestamp = Timestamp(metadata['X-Timestamp']).internal target_path = join(self._datadir, timestamp + self._extension) policy_idx=0): def create(self, size=None): self._bytes_per_sync, self._threadpool)

commit_message:
Switch to enable/disable Nova V2 XML Support

Nova will be removing support for the XML V2 API. So,
we need a way for folks to selectively enable/disable
the tests that exercise the API. Please see the related
change in devstack that is needed for this change to work.

Depends-On: I977fb6d72764d391b1c1b3b643968928792b34fd

Change-Id: I01d06741c8a0e68fe6bfc735273c5f19907ae6a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/14/134714/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Do not force use of [compute] image_ssh_user in scenario tests

_ssh_to_server passes the compute.image_ssh_user even though it is only
part of scenario testing. This issue does not cause a problem in the gate
because both compute.image_ssh_user and scenario.ssh_user are set to the
same value by devstack.

Change-Id: I9ba6e4e27f79b5ae3b1f4d68a824398532bbb03d

commit_message:
Adds support for browser compatibility for Horizon

Adds the support for browser compatibility check & notifies the
user to upgrade their browser. This function currently checks for
minimum browser version on which all mostly the functionally will
work.

In this patch, i have used jReject JavaScript library to implement
this browser detection functionality.

Change-Id: I3313014411528a19f2606e316117204bb84dffc4
Closes-Bug: #1156433

The error notice is generic without a giving a reason while creating
a new image and should state failed due to qouta problem.

commit_message:
Adds exception block to propogate the glance exceptions to Horizon

When an image creation fails due to glance file filter or insufficient
quota limit, the exception thrown by glance doesn't caught in the
horizon. So, this patch progogates the glance exception to horizon
glance api.

Change-Id: I09255cabaf43cb6c7a9275750c17820e694266cd
Partial-Bug: #1296722

commit_message:
Skip to poll and publish when no resources found

Currently, the polling agent will poll and publish even if no resources
found. Although no samples will be published in publishing process, the
polling record will be recorded in log files, this is easy to mislead.
This change skip to publish and record a clear skip-polling hint in
log if no resources found.

Change-Id: Ia0294d3308a1d709006f9cb772f35ea92badcb38

added_lines: The figure below shows the internals of a message broker node (referred to as a RabbitMQ node in the diagrams) when a single instance is deployed and shared in an OpenStack cloud. Every Cinder component connects to the message broker and, depending on its personality (for example a compute node or a network node), may use the queue either as an Invoker (such as API or Scheduler) or a Worker (such as Compute, Volume or Network). Invokers and Workers do not actually exist in the Cinder object model, but we are going to use them as an abstraction for sake of clarity. An Invoker is a component that sends messages in the queuing system via two operations: 1) rpc.call and ii) rpc.cast; a Worker is a component that receives messages from the queuing system and reply accordingly to rpc.call operations.The diagram below shows the message flow during an rpc.call operation:The diagram below the message flow during an rpc.cast operation:
deleted_lines: The figure below shows the internals of a message broker node (referred to as a RabbitMQ node in the diagrams) when a single instance is deployed and shared in an OpenStack cloud. Every Cinder component connects to the message broker and, depending on its personality (for example a compute node or a network node), may use the queue either as an Invoker (such as API or Scheduler) or a Worker (such as Compute, Volume or Network). Invokers and Workers do not actually exist in the Cinder object model, but we are going to use them as an abstraction for sake of clarity. Share migrations unit test between V2 & V2.1

This patch share unit tests of migrations between V2 & V2.1

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: If3a2d745933a5bf2b77c852be0652fb10246d0fa

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime from nova.api.openstack.compute.plugins.v3 import migrations from nova import context from nova import exception from nova import objects from nova.objects import base from nova.openstack.common.fixture import moxstubout from nova import test fake_migrations = [ { 'id': 1234, 'source_node': 'node1', 'dest_node': 'node2', 'source_compute': 'compute1', 'dest_compute': 'compute2', 'dest_host': '1.2.3.4', 'status': 'Done', 'instance_uuid': 'instance_id_123', 'old_instance_type_id': 1, 'new_instance_type_id': 2, 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2012, 10, 29, 13, 42, 2), 'updated_at': datetime.datetime(2012, 10, 29, 13, 42, 2), 'deleted_at': None, 'deleted': False }, { 'id': 5678, 'source_node': 'node10', 'dest_node': 'node20', 'source_compute': 'compute10', 'dest_compute': 'compute20', 'dest_host': '5.6.7.8', 'status': 'Done', 'instance_uuid': 'instance_id_456', 'old_instance_type_id': 5, 'new_instance_type_id': 6, 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2013, 10, 22, 13, 42, 2), 'updated_at': datetime.datetime(2013, 10, 22, 13, 42, 2), 'deleted_at': None, 'deleted': False } ] migrations_obj = base.obj_make_list( 'fake-context', objects.MigrationList(), objects.Migration, fake_migrations) class FakeRequest(object): environ = {"nova.context": context.get_admin_context()} GET = {} class MigrationsTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): def setUp(self): """Run before each test.""" super(MigrationsTestCase, self).setUp() self.controller = migrations.MigrationsController() self.context = context.get_admin_context() self.req = FakeRequest() self.req.environ['nova.context'] = self.context mox_fixture = self.useFixture(moxstubout.MoxStubout()) self.mox = mox_fixture.mox def test_index(self): migrations_in_progress = { 'migrations': migrations.output(migrations_obj)} for mig in migrations_in_progress['migrations']: self.assertIn('id', mig) self.assertNotIn('deleted', mig) self.assertNotIn('deleted_at', mig) filters = {'host': 'host1', 'status': 'migrating', 'cell_name': 'ChildCell'} self.req.GET = filters self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.controller.compute_api, "get_migrations") self.controller.compute_api.get_migrations( self.context, filters).AndReturn(migrations_obj) self.mox.ReplayAll() response = self.controller.index(self.req) self.assertEqual(migrations_in_progress, response) def test_index_needs_authorization(self): user_context = context.RequestContext(user_id=None, project_id=None, is_admin=False, read_deleted="no", overwrite=False) self.req.environ['nova.context'] = user_context self.assertRaises(exception.PolicyNotAuthorized, self.controller.index, self.req)

commit_message:
neutron-flavor-framework

Change-Id: Iac70f7332845e55ea6c75d6a7360dbd4ee021381
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/70/90070/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Neutron Flavor Framework ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-flavor-framework The purpose of a Flavor Framework is to provide an API that allows the user to choose the type of service by a set of advertised service capabilities rather than by a provider type or named vendor. Problem description =================== Need to create code infrastructure for the following list of tasks: * Vendor Driver of a Service must be able to declare a set of supported capabilities. * Service Plugin should be able to schedule service request to *some* driver which fully complies with requested requirements * User should be able to provide the requirements when creating service instance * Operator/Cloud Admin/User should be able to create set of capabilities for future usage. Such set of capabilities is called Flavor. Proposed change =============== Blueprint is tracking the following items: * Flavors API extension * Flavors persistence layer (DB plugin) * Common code for service plugins and drivers to support capabilities and scheduling. Particularly, a two-step scheduling is suggested. First step choses provider (driver) for the service with specified flavor. Second step is to call driver.schedule() to choose particular backend. Depending on the driver impelmentation, second step might be trivial (empty) The result of the first scheduling step is the association between the service instance and the driver (exactly as it is in provider framework). The result of the second step *might* be association between service instance and the backend. The example of such association could be pool_agent_binding used by haproxy provider of lbaas. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- The new data model Flavor is introduced. It has the following properties: * Id - autogenerated identificator * Service Type - a string constant of fixed list of string constants such as VPN, FIREWALL, LOADBALANCER, METERING, L3_ROUTER_NAT * Name - name of the Flavor * Tags - string property, consisting of key-value pairs: 'key1:value1,key2:value2' additional properties might be considered: * tenant_id - owning tenant * shared - boolean - whether the flavor is visible to all tenants Simple migration will be needed to introduce new model to the DB schema. REST API impact --------------- API impact consists of 2 parts: 1. Flavor API extension API extension adds flavor resource to the API. Its attributes reflect underlying db model (see above). Depending on preferred workflow, Flavor may be created by admin only, or by regular user as well. In latter case resource and model should have tenant_id and 'shared' properties. 2. Service API change Each service that is to use Flavor Framework needs to add flavor_id attribute to the service instance resource. For VPN such resource could be vpnconnection, for fwaas - firewall, for lbaas - VIP, for l3 plugin - router. At the same time 'provider' attribute that is now only available in lbaas for Pool object will be marked as deprecated and removed in the next release cycle. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The proposed feature should have end-user impact (on both CLI and UI). In particular, python-neutron client will be changed to manage flavors. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the API, discussion of how other plugins would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: enikanorov Other contributors: Work Items ---------- * Flavor Framework API, DB, scheduling code and driver interface * python-neutronclient * tempest API tests for flavor extension; new tests for services * Horizon integration Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Additional Tempest API tests are needed. Documentation Impact ==================== New API extension and workflow should be documented. So the change has DocImpact. References ========== * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/FlavorFramework

commit_message:
Add a project for OpenStack meetings descriptions

openstack-infra/gerrit-powered-agenda is being split into two
repositories: one for the code and one for the meetings descriptions
(so that review teams can be different and the code part can be reused).

This commit adds the repository for the meeting descriptions. After a
discussion with jeblair, I renamed it openstack-infra/irc-meetings.

Change-Id: Id75091087b7e36a17476fc6f47dad6d5ba473624

commit_message:
Fixing neutron-mlnx-agent service crash bug

Incorrect permissions for mlnx_conf.ini made the service crash.
The fix sets the owner as 'neutron' since the service is being run as neutron user.

Closes-bug: #1390185
Change-Id: Ieb0927d644c5a1d7eead12a32580f88d4d790e43
Signed-off-by: Gil Meir <gilmeir@mellanox.com>

because the Project-ID header was missing.
This change adds the required header.

commit_message:
Updating mellanox_openstack manifests for Fuel 6.0

* removed openibd workaround for upstart bug,
  this was fixed in the OFED drivers.

* removed mlnxvif package which is no longer used
  and previous vif_driver configurations.

Related-bug: #1386865
Closes-bug:  #1391797
Closes-bug:  #1353886

Change-Id: I9c670b8392f8b3ef93f1e6bf9f6514bf2bce6c2b
Signed-off-by: gilmeir <gilmeir@mellanox.com>

commit_message:
Removing mlnxvif Mellanox package

The package is removed since in Juno nova blocked the option
to add an external vif_driver, so this will no longer be in use.

Related-bug: #1391797

commit_message:
Increase volumes integration test rescan_timeout

This test is frequently failing, and it appears to be while waiting
for the volume to attach that the test fails.  It's not currently
clear if this is cinder flakiness or just not waiting long enough,
so increase the rescan_timeout to the same as the test timeout
so we can find out.

Partial-Bug: #1382300
Change-Id: Id93fcce3abcfbb06cb59e522f0b73fde35e29aa1

commit_message:
ensure dispatcher service is configured before rpc

there is a rare race condition where when the mq contains
notifications, the rpc service is configured before dispatcher so
it may attempt to start sending messages to dispatcher before it
has been configured. this patch ensures the dispatcher
configuration is done before starting rpc service.

Closes-Bug: #1384364

Change-Id: If4c3a225e0bd5ae6eefad072b844af1ef5786f3f
(cherry picked from commit 5df14763a5a88b9549066da04dac13ae2ad73144)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/95/130295/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # ensure dispatcher is configured before starting other services super(DispatchedService, self).start()

commit_message:
Enable os-collect-config on boot for packages

When using packages with the tripleo-image-elements
os-collect-config is no longer started on boot causing
things not to be configured at all.

This was a regression in dad3c0ccf1d95111630362f6b022c2cb2e1c6885
where we made global use of package installs within the TripleO
image elements.

Change-Id: I001c3d24882b3a4817cac767a8b7535d6b9cf247
Closes-bug: #1392751
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/56/134556/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eux os-svc-enable -n os-collect-config

commit_message:
object-ify flavors api and compute/api side of RPC

This change converts flavors to use objects instead of direct database
access. The rpcapi primitivizes objects before they go over the wire.

The flavors.add_flavor_access() and flavors.remove_flavor_access()
functions were also removed as flavor object add_access() and
remove_access() should be used instead.

Related to blueprint kilo-objects

Change-Id: I86432720b600e479d8d8b7f7531a2c85ab364319
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/57/122557/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'filter_properties' in build_inst_kwargs: flavor = build_inst_kwargs['filter_properties']['instance_type'] flavor_p = objects_base.obj_to_primitive(flavor) build_inst_kwargs['filter_properties'] = flavor_p

commit_message:
Fix inability to switch region via Switch Region dropdown

Prevent logged-in users redirect in case 'login'
view is used for switching the regions via modal form.

Change-Id: I47f26eea19e577998c7e3906a51900b51024eb43
Related-Bug: #1381413

supports XML and it leads to test failures once Neutron

Change-Id: I9ea9277e601746c257347bd64edab6f85bb24640
'}]
commit_message:
Fallback JSON network client if XML API is disabled

Some compute XML API tests expect the network API also
supports XML and it leads to test failures once Neutron
drop XML API support. This commit changes the network
client fallback to JSON mode if XML API is not supported
rather than skipping specific tests.

Change-Id: I9ea9277e601746c257347bd64edab6f85bb24640
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/37/131037/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.CONF.set_override('xml_api', True, group='network-feature-enabled')

commit_message:
Add ipmitool as dependency on RHEL/Fedora systems

Conductor has problems if ipmitool is absent on dev
machines. So add ipmitool as install prerequisite.

Closes-Bug: #1387495
Change-Id: I0f52f63ab2478634f6650657fd120e14a9b7925b

commit_message:
Improove speed of test

If docker container fails, test
will not wait until deployment timeout
and will fails too.
Depends on 132582

Change-Id: Ic2a1d3e0c9e0e1e514a749d603e91624ee1d0e02
Closes-bug: 1388002

commit_message:
Fix making targets other then 'iso' arg.

Building tagrets when 'iso' is not at the first place in 'make'
args list is failed because ./iso/isoroot dir doesn't exists.

Closes-Bug: #1384671

Change-Id: Idcfd107f63126620f462b26f9d0fa2a86a4f81ed

commit_message:
New node provision status detection

Use accumulated knowledge about nodes statuses
instead of trying to get info about all nodes
using one request.

Also:
* decrease polling frequency for node status
detection;
* increase timeout limit for mcollective request
about nodes statuses.

Also backport fix from master:
0085021fe327f6f910901b3ca55051b1df33a96e

Change-Id: I12dd30bc2fe304ac13f40d1cee1e2d25643dcacb
Closes-Bug: #1377105
(cherry picked from commit 33e357c06de708bb324885e529136cdc23361a6d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/91/134491/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sleep_not_greater_than(20) do nodes_types = node_type(proxy_reporter, task_id, nodes.map {|n| n['uid']}, 5) Astute.logger.debug("Still provisioning follow nodes: #{nodes_not_booted}") report_about_progress(proxy_reporter, provision_log_parser, target_uids, nodes) if nodes_not_booted.empty? Astute.logger.info "All nodes are provisioned"
deleted_lines: sleep_not_greater_than(5) do nodes_types = node_type(proxy_reporter, task_id, nodes.map {|n| n['uid']}, 2) if nodes.length == target_uids.length Astute.logger.info "All nodes #{target_uids.join(',')} are provisioned." Astute.logger.debug('Nodes list length is not equal to target ' + "nodes list length: #{nodes.length} != #{target_uids.length}") report_about_progress(proxy_reporter, provision_log_parser, target_uids, nodes)

commit_message:
Fix for migrating installation structures

Sync strategy changed for installation structures: modification_date
field is used as migration db sync field.
Field db_sync_field_name added into migration data.
Migration algorithm is refactored.

Change-Id: I070546ad39922008b213ec58a740cddc745c9b07
Blueprint: send-anon-usage

commit_message:
Fix circular reference error when live migration failed

When unexpected exception raised in live migration, the MigrationError
carry another original exception in it. But when oslo.message
serialize the exception, the circular reference error happended. This
patch just pass the exception as unicode string into MigrationError.

Change-Id: I4e449baae74bd9a15490ae7accbd2103bae90d57
Related-Bug: #1377644

commit_message:
Add tests on latest pacemaker improvements

-Add test on check monit service on compute nodes
-Add test on check pacemaker restart heat
in case of amqp connection loss

Related blueprint ha-test-improvements

Change-Id: I78f83dff15dda0ca8729962e0eb26f0ff490965f

commit_message:
Improve wait-for-* execs

Right after start haproxy marks all backends as UP. It marks
problem ones as DOWN only after health-checks. So we should not
rely on BACKEND status while INI is in process.

Change-Id: Ia3743d446826ee1a9d42799a83e14a911a577966
Related-bug: #1391180

commit_message:
Minor readability improvements to carbonara

Adding a brief description of the purpose of each timeserie class.

Also renaming some identifiers to be more explicit as their purpose.

Change-Id: I285547a8c73224ec10bdf65373f4570f99109cbe

commit_message:
Fix live migration api stuck when migrate to old nova node

Commit bc45c56f102cdef58840e02b609a89f5278e8cce disable instance
live migration between different verison node. If the two nodes
with different rpc version, will raise exception
LiveMigrationWithOldNovaNotSafe. But this exception didn't catch
as expected exception, that make the instance status stuck at
migrating. This patch add LiveMigrationWithOldNovaNotSafe as
expected exception.

Change-Id: I1dcee9181fd0ef293628b30766112f00792796ab
Closes-Bug: #1377644

commit_message:
Added separate log level for Rally debugging

  Default DEBUG log level produces a lot of output from off-site
  components, like OpenStack clients etc.
  This patch implements addition log level 'RALLYDEBUG' and cli/config
  options.

Change-Id: I58f29c5c69e23de297404a33e4e416e6844de4a3

commit_message:
Remove useless host parameter in virt

For host api, there are useless host params for
host_power_action and set_host_enable virt API,
this patch removes the useless host params.

Change-Id: I556278fc426a800f108da9129e42175da32dac49

commit_message:
Virt: update spawn signature to pass instance_type

This patch updates the spawn method to receive the instance type
as input. This will save database calls when spawning instances.

This is due to the fact that a number of the virt drivers are now
reading the flavor extra specs. There is no need to access the
database to get this information.

An example of where this will be used is
commit af4ec4ccb1ce5e635171c1d4b39f37fe0a5ccc34.

Change-Id: Ieebfcbc2478ba8d7036c1af30efbbf640aa7df73

commit_message:
Security Guide reference list update

Changing the bulleted list of reference URLs included in
chapters 8, 14, 15, and 17 into a bibliography format.

Change-Id: Ie3b061d74d806d01aa365712700bbc05b2792410

commit_message:
Convert qcow2 image to raw format when deploy

In iscsi deployment, currently the image are converted to raw format
in advance and then copied to the compute node later using DD command.

This patch supports convert on the fly, that means the image is converted
when copying the image to the compute node.

Change-Id: Iae8942c3f4d7c296966fe4325523034dd47e5556
Related-Bug: #1382164
